quest_title: A body of mass 60 kg is dragged with just enough force to start moving on a rough surface with coefficient of static and kinetic friction 0.5 and 0.4 respectively. On applying same force, the acceleration of body if it moves is
explanation_txt:
Limiting force of friction \((F_{f})\),

\(=\mu_{s} R\)
\(=0.5 \mathrm{mg}\)
\(=0.5 \times 600\)
\(=300 \mathrm{N}\)

If same force acts continously, then

\(F-E_{\hat{g}}=m a\)
\(\Rightarrow a=\cfrac{300-\mu_{k} m g}{m}\)
\(\quad=\cfrac{300-0.4 \times 600}{60}\)
\(\quad=\cfrac{300-240}{60}=1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\)

quest_title: A particle moves so that acceleration '\(a\)' is given by \(a = -bx\) where \(x\) is displacement from mean position and \(b\) is constant. The period of oscillation is
explanation_txt:
\(a=-\omega^{2} y\)

\(\therefore \omega^{2} =b\)

\(\Rightarrow \omega =\sqrt{b}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{T} =\cfrac{2 \pi}{\sqrt{b}}\)

quest_title: Magnification of a compound microscope is 30. Focal length of eye-piece is 5 \(\textit{cm}\) and the image is formed at a distance of distinct vision of 25 \(\textit{cm}\). The magnification of the objective lens is
explanation_txt:
\(M=\cfrac{v_{o} }{u_{o} } \left(1+\cfrac{D}{f_{e} } \right)=m_{o} \left(1+\cfrac{D}{f_{e} } \right)\)

\(\Rightarrow 30=m_{o} \left(1+\cfrac{25}{5} \right)=m_{0} \times 6\)

\(\Rightarrow m_{o} =5\)

quest_title: Refractive index of material is equal to tangent of polarizing angle. It is called
explanation_txt:
Brewster’s law states that the maximum polarization of light is achieved if the ray falls on a surface of a transparent medium in such a way that the refracted ray makes an angle of 90° with the reflected ray.

From snell's law,

\(\mu=\cfrac{\sin i}{\sin r}=\cfrac{\sin \theta_{B}}{\sin (180-90-\theta_{B}}=\cfrac{\sin \theta_{B}}{\cos \theta_{B}}=\tan \theta_{B}\)

quest_title: In the ionosphere electron execute \(2 \times 10^{6}\) rev/sec. Magnetic flux in this region is \(\left(M_{e}=9.1 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{kg}, e=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\right)\)
explanation_txt:
\(f=2 \times 10^{6}\) rev/sec \(\quad B=?\)
\(m_{e}=9.1 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{kg} \quad e=1.6 \times 10^{-19} \mathrm{C}\)
\(B e v=\cfrac{m v^{2}}{r}\)
\(B e=m w\)
\(B\left(\cfrac{e}{m}\right)=2 \pi f\)
\(B=\cfrac{2 \pi f}{\left(\cfrac{e}{m}\right)}\)

ans4_plain_text: 3 10 T

quest_title: A long horizontal rigidly supported wire carries a current \(i_a=96A\). Directly above it and parallel to it at a distance another wire of 0.144 N weight per meter carrying a current \(i_b=24A\), in a direction opposite to that of \(i_a\). If upper wire is to float in air due to magnetic repulsion, then its distance (in mm) from the lowest wire is
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{F}{l}=\cfrac{\mu_{0}}{4 \pi} \times \cfrac{2 i_{a} i_{b}}{r} \)
\(\Rightarrow 0.144=\cfrac{10^{-7} \times 2 \times 96 \times 24}{r} \)
\(\Rightarrow r=8.2 \mathrm{mm} \)

quest_title: Which of these has max. bond angle?
explanation_txt:
NO2- : 2 bond pairs + 1 lone pair

NO2 : 2 bond pairs + 1 lone electron

NO2+ : 2 bond pairs + 0 lone pair

And, the repulsion strength is: LP-LP > LP-BP > BP-BP

The order of bond angle is: NO2+ > NO2 > NO2-

The order of bond angle is: NO2+ > NO2 > NO2-

quest_title: The orthogonal projection of the point (2, -3) on the line x + y = 0 is:
explanation_txt:
Hints:
The image of the point P \((\alpha, \beta)\)
in the line \(x+y=0\) is \(P^{\prime}(-\beta,-\alpha)\)
the projection of \((\alpha, \beta)\) on the line \(x+y=0\)
is the mid point of PP'.
\(\begin{aligned} P(2,-3) & \rightarrow P^{\prime}(3,-2) \\ \text { Mid point } &=\left(\cfrac{2+3}{2}, \cfrac{-3-2}{2}\right) \\ &=\left(\cfrac{5}{2},-\cfrac{5}{2}\right) \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: The equation of the ellipse whose vertices are \(( \pm 5,0 )\) and foci are \(( \pm 4,0 )\) is
explanation_txt:
By question, \( (\pm a , 0) = ( \pm 5, 0) \) and \( \pm ae,0) = ( \pm 4,0) \.

So, \( a = 5, e = 4/5 \)

Since \( c^2 = a^2 - b^2 \) where \( c = ae \), we get \( 4^2 = 5^2 - b^2 \Rightarrow b = 3 \)

So, equation of ellipse is \( \cfrac{x^2}{25} + \cfrac{y^2}{9} = 1 \)

Upon simplification \( 9x^2 + 25y^2 = 225 \)

quest_title: If \(5^{th} \) term of a H.P. is \(\cfrac{1}{45} \)and \(11^{th} \) term is \(\cfrac{1}{69} \), then its \(16^{th} \) term will be
explanation_txt:
Let \(5^{th}\) and \(11^{th}\) terms of the corresponding AP be \(45\) and \(69\) respectively.

\( a + 4d = 45 \quad \quad (i) \\ a + 10d = 69 \quad \quad (ii) \)

Solving these equations,

\( a = 29, d = 4 \)

So, \( t_{16} = a + 15d = 89 \)

So, the term of HP is \( \cfrac{1}{89} \)

quest_title: A element 'X' is radioactive and element'Y' is stable. 'X' is present as 1% of atoms of element 'Y' of atomic mass 80. The activity after 10 hours in 10 g of 'Y' if half life of 'X' is 5 hours
explanation_txt:
No. of atoms of \(\mathrm{Y}=\cfrac{6.02 \times 10^{23}}{80} \times 10 \\ \qquad = 7.5 \times 10^{22}\)

\(\begin{aligned} \text { No. of atoms of } \mathrm{X}\left(\mathrm{N}_{\mathrm{o}}\right) &=1 \% \text { of } \mathrm{Y} \\ &=7.5 \times 10^{20} \end{aligned}\)

\(\begin{aligned} \mathrm{N}=\mathrm{N}_{0}\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\cfrac{t}{T_{1/2}}} &=7.5 \times 10^{20}\left(\cfrac{1}{2}\right)^{105} \\ &=1.88 \times 10^{20} \end{aligned}\)

\(\begin{aligned} \text { Activity } &=\lambda \mathrm{N}=\cfrac{0.693}{\mathrm{T}_{1 / 2}} \mathrm{N} \\ &=\cfrac{0.693}{5 \times 3600} \times 1.88 \times 10^{20} \\ &=7.2 \times 10^{15} / \mathrm{s} \end{aligned}\)
question_plain_title: A element 'X' is radioactive and element'Y' is stable. 'X' is present as 1% of atoms of element 'Y' of atomic mass 80. The activity after 10 hours in 10 g of 'Y' if half life of 'X' is 5 hours
explanation_plain_text: No. of atoms of
ans1_plain_text: 7.210 /s
ans2_plain_text: 7.210 /s
ans3_plain_text: 7.210 /s
ans4_plain_text: 7.210 /s

quest_title: The maximum weight of an aircraft with a wing area 50m\({}^{2}\) flying horizontally having velocity 150m/s & 140m/s above & below the wing is (density of air = 1.29kg/m\({}^{3}\))
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{P}_{1}+\cfrac{\rho v_{1}^{2}}{2}=P_{2}+\cfrac{\rho v_{2}^{2}}{2}\)

\(\Rightarrow \mathrm{P}_{1}-\mathrm{P}_{2}=\cfrac{\rho}{2}\left(v_{2}^{2}-v_{1}^{2}\right)\)
\(\therefore \mathrm{F}=\Delta \mathrm{PA}=\cfrac{\rho}{2}\left(v_{2}^{2}-v_{1}^{2}\right) \times 50\)

quest_title: A particle having mass 0.5 kg is projected against gravity with a speed of 98 m/s at an angle 60\(^{\circ}\) above horizontal. The change in momentum after 10 sec is
explanation_txt:
Vertical velocity after 10 sec is
\(V_{y}=u \sin \theta-g t \)
\(V_{y}=98 \sin 60-10 \times 10 \)
\(V_{y}=-15.1 \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s} \)

Change in momentum \(=m v \sin \theta-\left(-m V_{y}\right)\)

\(\quad=0.5 \times 98 \sin 60+0.5 \times 15.1=50 \mathrm{NS}\)

quest_title: The driver cell of a potentiometer has an emf of 2v and negligible internal resistance. The potentiometer wire has a resistance of 3\(\Omega\). The resistance needed in series with, the wire if a p.d. of 5mv is required across the whole wire is
explanation_txt: \(\begin{aligned} \text { P.d across AB} &=i \cdot R_{AB } \\ &=\cfrac{2}{R+3} \times 3 \\ \text { or, } \cfrac{5}{1000}=& \cfrac{2}{R+3} \times 3 \\ \Rightarrow R=& 1197 \Omega \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: A motor having an armature of resistance \(2 \Omega\) is designed to operate 220 V mains. A full speed, it develops a back e.m.f. of 210 volt. When the motor is running at fll speed, the current in armature is
explanation_txt:
The armature current is given by

\(i=\cfrac{E-\text { back emf }}{\text { Resistance }}=\cfrac{220-210}{2}=5 \mathrm{Amp} \)

quest_title: A dip circle is so set that it moves freely in the magnetic meridian. In this position, the angle of dip is 40. Now the dip circle is rotated so that the plane in which the needle moves make an angle of 30\(^\circ\) with the magnetic meridian. In this position, the needle will dip by the angle
explanation_txt:
Let new angle of dip be \(^{\circ} \theta^{\prime}\) then,
\(\begin{aligned} \tan \theta &=\cfrac{\tan 40^{\circ}}{\cos 30^{\circ}}=\tan 40^{\circ} \times \cfrac{2}{\sqrt{3}} \\ \tan \theta>\tan 40^{\circ} & \therefore \theta>40^{\circ} \end{aligned}\)

quest_title: The wavelength of radiation emitted is \(\lambda\)\({}_{o}\) when an electron jumps from the third to the second orbit of hydrogen atom. For the electron jump from the fourth to the second orbit of the hydrogen atom, the wavelength of radiation emitted will be
explanation_txt:
\(\cfrac{1}{\lambda_{0}}=\mathrm{R}\left(\cfrac{1}{2^{2}}-\cfrac{1}{3^{2}}\right)=\cfrac{5 \mathrm{R}}{36}\)
or, \(\mathrm{R}=\cfrac{36}{5 \lambda_{0}}\)
Again, \(\cfrac{1}{\lambda}=\mathrm{R}\left[\cfrac{1}{2^{2}}-\cfrac{1}{4^{2}}\right]=\cfrac{3 \mathrm{R}}{16}\)

quest_title: Zinc obtains resistance against atmospheric corrosion because of a coating of _____ develops on its surface:
explanation_txt:
Zinc obtains the protective layer of basic zinc carbonate on reaction with atmospheric oxygen, moisture and carbondioxide:

\( Zn + O_2 + CO_2 + H_2O \to ZnCO_3 \cdot 3Zn(OH)_2 \)

quest_title: Neutralization of an acid with a base invariably results in the production of
explanation_txt:
Neutralization is a chemical reaction in which acid and base react to form salt and water.

\(H^+\) from acid and \(OH^-\) from base combine to give \(H_2O\)

Eg \(HCl + NaOH \to NaCl +H_2O\)

quest_title: In a \( \Delta A B C , \cfrac { \cos C + \cos A } { c + a } + \cfrac { \cos B } { b } \) is equal to
explanation_txt:
\( \begin{array} { l } { \cfrac { \cos C + \cos A } { c + a } + \cfrac { \cos B } { b } } \\ { = \cfrac { ( b \cos C + c \cos B ) + ( b \cos A + a \cos B ) } { b ( c + a ) } } \end{array} \)

\( \begin{array} { l } { = \cfrac { a + c } { b ( c + a ) } , ( \text { using Projection formulae } ) } \\ { = \cfrac { 1 } { b } } \end{array}\)
